SlagDoc:Primitives

From Plasmaworks

Jump to: navigation, search

Primitives are the simple numerical building blocks of more complex data structures. In Slag they are always by-value, meaning that you can't have pointers or references to primitives and that assignments always make a copy of data.

Unlike the primitives in most languages, Slag primitives have well-defined bit sizes that are guaranteed to remain constant across platforms.

Contents

  • 1 Real64
  • 2 Real32
  • 3 Int64
  • 4 Int32
  • 5 Char
  • 6 Byte
  • 7 Logical

Real64

A 64-bit floating point real number. Equivalent to type double in many languages.

Literal Real64 values: 3.14159, 0.0, -4.9, NaN, infinity, -infinity, pi, e

Note: two NaN numbers are not considered equivalent. "x = NaN; println(x == NaN)" will print "false". Use "x.is_NaN" instead.


Real32

A 32-bit floating point real number. Equivalent to type float in many languages.

Literal Real32 values: Real32(3.14159), Real32(0), Real32(-4.9)


Int64

A 64-bit signed integer. Equivalent to type long in Java with range -2^63..(2^63)-1.

Literal Int64 values: Int64(3), Int64(0)


Int32

A 32-bit signed integer. Equivalent to type int in Java with range -2^31..(2^31)-1

Literal Int32 values: 3, 0, -2


Char

A 16-bit unsigned integer. Equivalent to type char in Java with range 0..65535. Char values print out as their Unicode symbols.

Literal Char values: 'A', '!', '3', Char(66)


Byte

An 8-bit unsigned integer. Equivalent to type "unsigned char" in most C/C++ implementations with range 0..255.

Literal Byte values: Byte(0), Byte(255)


Logical

Individual Logical values are 32-bit while Logical arrays have 8-bit values. Logical values are similar to Java's boolean type except that they have three states instead of two: true, false, and void.

Literal Logical values: true, false, void, gt, eq, lt

The values "gt", "eq", and "lt" are aliases for "true", "false", and "void", respectively, and are make more sense in some situations.

Logical is fully compatible with the usage of the Java-style Boolean, with both "false" and "void" counting as "false" in most situations, with an explicit comparison required to distinguish "false" from "void". The tables below show how different logical values are interpreted in different situations:


x if (x) if (not x) if (x == true) if (x == false) if (x == void)
true true false true false false
false false true false true false
void false true false false true
